fields.value: Replication Data for: Reassessing the economic value of Advanced level Mathematics

dsDescriptionValue.value: In the late 1990s, Dolton and Vignoles (1999) examined the economic return to A-level mathematics based upon a series of log-linear models of earnings in the 1958 National Child Development Survey (NCDS) and the National Survey of 1980 Graduates and Diplomates. Their core finding was that A-level mathematics had a unique earnings premium of 7-10% at age 33.  In recent years, this finding has contributed to the governmentâ€™s agenda of increasing participation in post-16 study of advanced mathematics in England. Given that the 1958 NCDS participants are now 57 years old, this paper repeats this important work using the 1970 British Cohort Study (BCS). Updated models are used to investigate whether the A-level mathematics premium also existed at age 34 for the 1970 BCS participants. There does appear to be a return of approximately 11% when replicating the original model closely but the robustness of this result depends on the model specification, sample size and the handling of missing data. We consider theoretical explanations of these findings and their implications for policy and future research.

files.description:
The analysis file is designed to generate tables from the 
imputation object, coefficient plots for model 5 and 6, run simulations based on the 
inferences generated by the final two models and to graph the histograms to describe 
their distributions.
files.label: 2015_08_26_WP1_Analysis.r

files.description:
The imputation file is more suited to running on a 
High Performance Computing (HPC) cluster as the task will take many hours, 
but can be run on a normal desktop PC.

files.description:
The munge file is designed to load, merge and clean 
the dataset for the final analyses. This can be completed on a normal desktop PC.
